author: Debbie Cuthbertson
title: Put out your bricks? Ai Weiwei plans new artwork in response to LEGO ban for National Gallery of Victoria show
text:
Ai Weiwei at the opening of his exhibition Royal Academy exhibition in London last month. Photo: Frank Augstein 
Ai Weiwei says Lego refused order for Melbourne exhibition on political grounds Ai Weiwei to make fourth visit to Australia for National Gallery of Victoria exhibition Ai Weiwei brings Forever Bicycles sculpture to NGV Ai Weiwei plans to create a new artwork using crowd-sourced LEGO after the Danish toy maker refused on "political grounds" permission for him to use its plastic bricks in his upcoming National Gallery of Victoria show.
The Chinese artist and activist revealed his plan in a post from his Instagram account following a social media backlash against LEGO after Ai announced the company had refused the gallery's request for the artist to use the toys to create an installation for Andy Warhol|Ai Weiwei , opening at the Melbourne gallery in December.
He was flooded with offers of LEGO donations from artists and his followers around the world on social media.
Advertisement "In response to Lego's refusal and the overwhelming public response, Ai Weiwei has now decided to make a new work to defend freedom of speech and 'political art', he said in a new post overnight.
"Ai Weiwei Studio will announce the project description and Lego collection points in different cities. This is the first phase of the coming projects."
  In September 2015 Lego refused to sell Ai Weiwei Studio a bulk order of Lego bricks for Ai's artworks to be exhibited at the National Gallery of Victoria in Melbourne on the basis of the works' "political" nature. Ai posted this notice on his Instagram on Friday, October 23rd. Lego's position triggered a torrent of outrage on social media against this assault on creativity and freedom of expression. Numerous supporters offered to donate Lego to Ai. In response to Lego's refusal and the overwhelming public response, Ai Weiwei has now decided to make a new work to defend freedom of speech and "political art". Ai Weiwei Studio will announce the project description and Lego collection points in different cities. This is the first phase of the coming projects. 
A photo posted by Ai Weiwei (@aiww) on Oct 25, 2015 at 10:37am PDT 
On Friday he revealed the company's refusal, and over the weekend posted further details about the communication between the gallery and the company.
On Sunday he reposted hundreds of messages of support via Instagram and Twitter and revealed further details - in a post featuring LEGO bricks in a toilet bowl - about communications between the company and the gallery regarding his installation.
"It must be clear to the public that the LEGO Group has not sponsored or endorsed the art work/project. Therefore I am very sorry to let you know that we are not in a position to support the exhibition Andy Warhol | Ai Weiwei by supplying the bulk order. The museum's curatorial team contacted Lego to place a bulk order and received Lego's reply via email on 12 September 2015," he wrote.
"We regret to inform you that it is against our corporate policy to indicate our approval of any unaffiliated activities outside the LEGO licensing program," he said the company had told the gallery.
"It must be clear to the public that the LEGO Group has not sponsored or endorsed the art work/project," it wrote to the NGV.

"Therefore I am very sorry to let you know that we are not in a position to support the exhibition Andy Warhol | Ai Weiwei by supplying the bulk order." 
The gallery said the installation planned for the Melbourne show, one of several large-scale commissions specifically for the exhibition, would continue despite LEGO's refusal.
"[Ai] is working on a new installation focusing on Australian activists, advocates and champions of human rights, freedom of expression, freedom of information and the internet," NGV contemporary curator Max Delany said.  

"The work is currently in development and we are very excited to see the final form that this will take."
